data.title: 100 Classic Vietnamese Last Names: With Meanings
data.meta_description: Our information-packed list includes 100 Vietnamese last names, including their origins, unique meanings, and accurate pronunciations.
data.text:
Vietnam has a fascinating history that includes a thousand-year Chinese occupation and modern-day independence. This unique history has certainly influenced Vietnamese last names over time, making it essential to recognize the particular differences to understand them better.

Our fascinating guide ahead has all the backstory you could ask for and more. Youâ€™ll discover their origin, variations, and famous namesakes. Along the way, youâ€™ll come to appreciate the traditions behind Vietnamese family names and those who use them.

Gender

Sort by

Style

100 Popular Vietnamese Surnames

These Vietnamese last names pack a punch when it comes to meaning and tradition.

Ãi

Like many Vietnamese last names, Ãi first appeared in China out of a surname meaning â€œto love,â€ â€œto be fond of,â€ â€œto like,â€ or â€œaffection.â€ It can also mean â€œmugwortâ€ and is associated with similar Mandarin and Taiwanese surnames.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: To love

Pronunciation: AEY

Namesakes: AÃ¬ QÄ«ng, a Chinese poet known for Dayanheâ€”My Nanny. Ai Baojun, the Vice Mayor of Shanghai from 2012 to 2015.

Popularity: Ãi ranked 610th worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 83rd in Vietnam in 2014.

Anh

Anh comes from the Sino-Vietnamese â€œanh,â€ meaning â€œpetal,â€ â€œflower,â€ â€œbrave,â€ or â€œhero.â€ Some associated Anh with the Chinese YÄ«ng, which sometimes means â€œintellectualâ€ and â€œbright.â€

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Flower, petal

Pronunciation: AEYNH

Variations: An

Namesakes: Anh Do, a Vietnamese-Australian writer and winner of the 2017 Peopleâ€™s Choice Award.

Popularity: Anh ranked 804th worldwide and is mainly used in Vietnam, ranking 23rd in 2014.

Bach

Bach is included in many Vietnamese surnames used by the Chinese community in Vietnam. In addition to â€œwhite,â€ it also means â€œsnowy,â€ â€œpure,â€ and â€œto make clear.â€ Bach is known as Bai in Chinese and Baek in Korean.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: White

Pronunciation: BAAK

Variations: Baek, Baik

Namesakes: Bach Hung Khang, a Vietnamese scientist and pioneer in information technology. Tráº§n Báº¡ch Äáº±ng, a Vietnamese communist leader known for the book VÃ¡n bÃ i láº­t ngá»­a.

Popularity: Bach is rare worldwide and primarily used in Vietnam, where it ranked 114th in 2014.

Ban

Ban is derived from Mi, a royal surname dating back to the ancient Chinese State of Chu. Itâ€™s also related to the occupation of a â€œhelper,â€ â€œsupporter,â€ or for something living in a forest.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Of the forest

Pronunciation: BAAN

Variations: Pan

Namesakes: Ban Biao, a 1st-century Chinese historian known for beginning the Book of Han.

Popularity: Ban ranked 1,417th worldwide, is mostly used in China, and ranked 213th in Vietnam in 2014.

Bao

Bao is taken from the Sino-Vietnamese â€œbáº£o,â€ meaning â€œtreasureâ€ or â€œjewel.â€ Its other meanings include â€œbundle,â€ â€œpackage,â€ and â€œguarantee.â€

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Treasure

Pronunciation: BAOW

Variations: Pao

Namesakes: Bao Yingying, a Chinese saber fencer and silver medalist at the 2008 Summer Olympics. Bao Beiâ€™er, a Chinese actor known for Welcome to Shama Town (2010).

Popularity: Bao ranked 220th worldwide, is mainly used in China, and ranked 20th in Vietnam in 2014.

Bong

Bong derives from the Chinese HuÃ¡ng, meaning â€œyellow,â€ and WÃ¡ng, meaning â€œking.â€ It even appears in Korea, where it means â€œmythical bird.â€

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: King

Pronunciation: BOHNG

Variations: Pong

Namesakes: Diana Bong Siong Lin, a Malay wushu taolu coach and bronze medalist at the 2006 Asian Games. Bong Chang-won, a South Korean wrestler who competed at the 1960 Summer Olympics.

Popularity: Bong is rare worldwide, primarily used in Malaysia, and ranked 308th in Vietnam in 2014.

BÃ¹i

BÃ¹iâ€™s original Chinese meaning refers to a â€œlong and flowing garment.â€ It appears as Pei in Chinese and Bae in Korean. BÃ¹i may also be related to the Vietnamese â€œbui,â€ meaning â€œcloud.â€

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Long flowing (garment)

Pronunciation: BUW-ee

Namesakes: BÃ¹i ÄÃ¬nh DÄ©nh, the Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of Vietnam to the Russian Federation from 2007 to 2011. BÃ¹i Táº¥n TrÆ°á»ng, a Vietnamese footballer for HÃ  Ná»™i.

Popularity: Bui ranked 260th worldwide and is mostly used in Vietnam, ranking 9th in 2023.

Cao

Cao originates in Mandarin Chinese, meaning â€œconductâ€ and â€œbehavior.â€ Cao ranks 30th among popular surnames in mainland China and 58th in Taiwan in 2019.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Grasp

Pronunciation: KAOW

Variations: TÃ o

Namesakes: Cao Lu, a Chinese singer with the South Korean girl group Fiestar. Cao Yupeng, a Chinese snooker player who won the 2011 Asian Under-21 Championship.

Chang

Chang means â€œconstantâ€ or â€œoftenâ€ and is linked to the Japanese ChÅ. Itâ€™s a more modern form of the original Vietnamese TrÆ°Æ¡ng. Chang was first used by descendants of Chang Yi, who lived during the reign of the Yellow Emperor.

ChÃª

ChÃª is most common among the southern Vietnamese Cham. It can mean â€œcarriageâ€ or â€œcartâ€ in Chinese and originated with Che Ou, a famous ancient astrologer.

Meaning: Carriage

Pronunciation: CHEAY

Variations: Chae

Chim

Besides â€œbird,â€ Chim means â€œGod will judgeâ€ in Vietnamese. Its origin is also Cambodian, where it means â€œpracticing divination.â€ Chimâ€™s Chinese equivalent is Zhan.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Bird

Pronunciation: CHIHM

Namesakes: Chim Pui-chung, a member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong from 1991 to 1997. Jim Chim Sui-man (born ZhÄn RuÃ¬wÃ©n), a Hong Kong actor known for You Shoot, I Shoot (2001).

Popularity: Chim is rare worldwide, mainly used in Cambodia, and ranked 380th in 2014.

CÃ´ng

CÃ´ng means â€œfair,â€ â€œequitable,â€ and â€œpublicâ€ in Sino-Vietnamese. Itâ€™s a Chinese surname found in a particular community in Wendeng, China. CÃ´ng also appears in Japan, Korea, and Mongolia.

Variations: Cung

Namesakes: Cong Peiwu, the Chinese Ambassador to Canada since 2019. Cong Yanxia, a Chinese handball player who competed at the 1996 Summer Olympics.

Popularity: CÃ´ng ranked 1,072nd worldwide, is primarily used in China, and ranked 85th in 2014.

CÃºc

Like many Vietnamese family names, CÃºc has multiple meanings. It means â€œbent,â€ â€œcrooked,â€ â€œtune,â€ and â€œsong.â€ It also refers to Chrysanthemums, a Mayan name meaning â€œQuetzal bird.â€

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Bent

Pronunciation: KOOK

Popularity: CÃºc is rare worldwide, mainly used in Guatemala, and ranked 458th in Vietnam in 2014.

CÆ°á»ng

CÆ°á»ngâ€™s meanings include â€œstrong,â€ plus â€œtoughâ€ or â€œresilient.â€ It derives from the Han Vietnamese language, where it also means â€œstubbornâ€ and â€œunyielding.â€ CÆ°á»ng is sometimes a nickname for kids who have great prospects in life.

Namesakes: Cuong Ngo, a Vietnamese director known for The Golden Pin (2009). Cuong Vu, a Vietnamese-American jazz trumpeter and the first Vietnamese-American to win a Grammy Award.

Äáº·ng

Äáº·ng means both â€œpartyâ€ and â€œassociation.â€ It also refers to the Clan of Man in the State of Deng during the Chinese Spring and Autumn period.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Association

Pronunciation: DAENG

Variations: Deng

Namesakes: Äáº·ng Thá»‹ Ngá»c Thá»‹nh, the Vice President of Vietnam from 2016 to 2021. Äáº·ng Minh, a Vietnamese director, awarded the Nikkei Asia Prize for Culture in 1999.

Danh

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Famous

Pronunciation: DAEYN

Namesakes: Danh Quach, a Vietnamese-American businessman known in Orange Countyâ€™s Little Saigon. Danh VÃµ, a Vietnamese artist who won the 2012 Hugo Boss Prize.

ÄÃ o

Like other names on our list, ÄÃ oâ€™s meanings donâ€™t always match. It can describe â€œpotteryâ€ and â€œpleased.â€ ÄÃ o is also the name of an ethnic group from China who arrived in Vietnam in the 12th- and 13th-centuries.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Pottery

Pronunciation: DAOW

Namesakes: ÄÃ o VÄƒn Phong, a Vietnamese footballer for Sanna KhÃ¡nh HÃ²a BVN. Julie C. Dao, a Vietnamese-American fantasy writer known for Forest of a Thousand Lanterns (2017).

DiÃªm

DiÃªm means â€œmysterious,â€ â€œsubtle,â€ and â€œexquisite.â€ Itâ€™s also a girlâ€™s name in Vietnam, where it means â€œbeautiful,â€ â€œcharming,â€ or â€œkind-hearted.â€

Origin: Vietnamese

Meaning: Mysterious

Pronunciation: DYEM

Variations: Dieu

Namesakes: Ryan Diem, an American football player for the Indianapolis Colts.

Diá»‡p

Diá»‡pâ€™s Chinese-associated meanings include â€œto be in harmony,â€ â€œleaf,â€ and â€œpage.â€ It also refers to a specific time in Chinese history.

Äinh

Äinh means â€œpalaceâ€ or â€œtempleâ€ in Vietnamese, along with â€œboyâ€ or â€œmanâ€ in Chinese. It also refers to a 10th-century Vietnamese imperial dynasty, which is why itâ€™s a unisex name for noble babies.

Duy

Giang

Giang is the Vietnamese equivalent of the Chinese Jiang, meaning â€œriver.â€ The structure among Vietnamese last names includes a â€œgâ€ being pronounced as â€œzâ€ or â€œjâ€ when followed by â€œeâ€ or â€œi.â€

GiÃ¡p

HÃ²a

HoÃ ng

Meaning: Yellow

Há»©a

Há»©a means â€œto allow,â€ â€œto promise,â€ or â€œto praise.â€ It sometimes refers to the Chinese people and also means â€œflower.â€ The Cantonese equivalents are Wah and Fa.

Huynh

In Chinese, Huá»³nh means â€œyellow,â€ â€œgolden,â€ or â€œhaving the color of gold.â€ It currently ranks 7th in China and 5th in Vietnam, while it goes by Hwang in Korea.

Origin: Vietnamese, Chinese

Meaning: Older brother

Pronunciation: HOOWN

KhÃ¡nh

Khuu

Kieu

Kim

Kim refers to â€œgoldâ€ or â€œmetal,â€ but can also mean â€œbrightâ€ and â€œbeautiful.â€ Though a Vietnamese surname, Kim is the most popular Korean surname and appears as Jin in Chinese.

LÃ¢m

LÃ¢m describes a â€œwoodâ€ or â€œforest,â€ while its Mandarin variant is Lin. Itâ€™s often a surname for Chinese populations in southern China and Hong Kong, especially those who speak Cantonese.

LÃ£nh

LÃª

In Vietnam, LÃª is a royal and noble name inspired by the 15th-century LÃª Dynasty. Itâ€™s ranked in the top four Vietnamese surnames of Mandarin or Cantonese speakers. It means â€œdepend onâ€ in Chinese as Lai, the name of a state in the Henan province.

LÃª Ngoc

LÃª ThÃ¡nh

LÃª ThÃ¡nh is linked with Chinese last names as with other Vietnamese surnames. It means â€œto succeed,â€ â€œfinish, to complete,â€ or â€œto accomplish.â€ LÃª ThÃ¡nh also means â€œall rightâ€ and â€œbrilliant.â€

LÃ´

LÃ´ means â€œto sift,â€ but also carries other meanings, from â€œrice vesselâ€ to the â€œdescendants of Luo.â€ Luo was a feudal state existing under the ancient Chinese Shang dynasty.

Máº¡c

Máº¡nh

Meo

Vietnamese Family Names FAQs

What Are Three Common Vietnamese Last Names?

Nguyen is overwhelmingly the most common among Vietnamese last names, used by about 40% of Vietnamese people. It comes from the Chinese â€œruan,â€ referring to a Chinese stringed instrument. Other common Vietnamese surnames include Le, Tran, Pham, and Hoang. In Vietnam, only 14 surnames account for over 90% of the population.

Are Vietnamese Last Names First?

Vietnamese last names are arranged with the surname first, followed by the middle name (if any), and the given name last. This is referred to as the â€œeastern name order.â€ Vietnamese family names are passed down from parents and used by all siblings the same way they are in other countries.

Why Do Vietnamese Have Chinese Last Names?

Vietnamese surnames first appeared in 111 BCE, when the Chinese Han Dynasty began their occupation of Vietnam for one thousand years, until around 939 CE. This greatly affected the number of Vietnamese last names with Chinese origins. The naming order that includes using the surname first also came from this thousand-year Chinese occupation.

About the Author

Maryana Vestic

Maryana Vestic is a Brooklyn-based writer, editor, and food photographer with a background in entertainment Business Affairs. She studied film at NYU, Irish Theatre Studies at Trinity College Dublin, and has an MFA in Creative Writing Nonfiction from The New School.
